column29: Adult patients referred for neuropsychological evaluation at an academic medical center from 2018 to 2021, with a clinical diagnosis of ADHD based on the comprehensive protocol of the study

column176: Diagnosed with ADHD based on DSM-5 criteria by a board-certified clinical neuropsychologist using a standardized multimodal diagnostic assessment protocol that included a detailed clinical interview, review of medical and psychiatric history, symptom questionnaires, and a comprehensive neuropsychological test battery
column273: SCWT WR raw (Stroop Color and Word Test word reading trial), SCWT assesses cognitive flexibility and processing speed through 3 trials: word reading, color naming, and color-word interference, cut of 75 or less
column276: Tests were administered via manual-specified standardized procedures and were scored using age or demographically adjusted norms, as appropriate
column408: DCT (Dot Counting Test), a freestanding performance validity test, admistered together with Stroop Color and Word Test hrough 3 trials: word reading, color naming, and color-word interference; the word reading and color naming trials were used as embedded performance validity tests to evaluate the validity of neuropsychological test performance, and RAVLT (Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test), which assesses verbal/auditory learning and memory, and the BVMT-R (Brief Visuospatial Memory Test-Revised), which evaluates visuospatial learning and memory; as well as WAIS-IV Digit Span embedded performance validity indicators (Reliable Digit Span [RDS], RDS-Working Memory, RDS-Revised, Age-Corrected Scaled Score) used to detect non-credible cognitive performance; plus Clinical Assessment of Attention Deficit-Adult Negative Impression and Infrequency scales, and the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory-2-Restructured Form validity scales (F-r, Fp-r, Fs, FBS-r, RBS) combined in machine learning model to assess noncredible (feigned/exaggerated) symptom reporting; also a combination of performance tests (Rey 15-item Test Recall and Recognition, Dot Counting Test E-Score, Reliabile Digit Span, Stroop Word Reading T-Score, Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test-Effort Score) to determine an intra-individual variability index (intra-individual standard deviation, coefficient of varienace, hit reaction standard deviation T score, hit reaction Tscore; mean T-score performance across all tasks); in addition to Integrating 6 indicators - Combination of WAIS-IV Symbol Search age-corrected scaled score (equal to smaller than 6), WAIS-IV Coding age-corrected scaled score (equal or smaler than6), WAIS-IV Letter-Number Sequencing age-corrected scaled score (equal or smaller than 7), SCWT Word Reading T-score (equal or smaller than 25), TMT-B T-score (equal or smaller than 34), and Lexical Fluency FAS T-score (equl or smaller than 34); cut-off failing 2; adminstered together with the NI (Negative Impression), IF (Infrequency), and PI (Positive Impression) scales; some patients received the BAARS-IV (Barkley Adult ADHD Rating Scale – Fourth Edition) using extreme cut-scores on the Current Total (≥56) and Current Sluggish Cognitive Tempo (SCT) (≥29) scales as symptom validity indicators to detect overreporting; in addition, some patients received WAIS-IV Letter-Number Sequencing, CPT-3, Trail Making Test, and Stroop Test

column273: QbTest (Quantified Behavior Test), cut-off score of ≥1.5; continuous performance test measuring inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity combined with activity levels which are measured by an infrared motion tracking camera; participants are asked to sit 1m from a monitor which the infrared motion tracking camera is attached to, and to hold a handheld responder; consists of 600 stimuli presented on the monitor, each stimulus is present for 200ms, followed by an interval of 2000ms; stimulus consists of red or blue circles and squares; participants are instructed to only press the responder when the stimuli they see matches the previous stimuli in color or shape; attention is measured by number of correctly identified targets, reaction time, and variability of reaction time; impulsivity is measured by incorrect responses, and hyperactivity is measured using the motion- tracking system using the infrared camera (captures movement by tracking a reflective headband); camera captures movement throughout the whole of the task at a frequency of 50 samples a second and with spatial resolution of 1/27 mm per infrared camera unit
column276: Adult version of QbTest+ was used consisting of unconditional identical pair paradigm to avoid floor to ceiling effects, testing conducted in a specialist ADHD/Autism clinic setting; standard QbTest administration procedures followed, with computer-based tasks and infrared headband motion tracking; participants are instructed that there will be time for a 5-minute practice before they begin, and that accuracy and speed is the objective
column799: The QbTest+ demonstrated 70% sensitivity and 43% specificity, failing to effectively differentiate between those diagnosed with ADHD and those without a diagnosis after full clinical assessment.

column318: Brain perfusion SPECT (single-photon emission computed tomography), photon emission was captured using a high-resolution Picker Prism 3000 triple-headed gamma camera with fan beam collimator with data collected in 128 × 128 matrices, yielding 120 images per scan separated by 3 degrees spanning 360 degrees; a low pass filter applied with a high cutoff and Chang attenuation correction; patients sat upright in a quiet, dimly lit room with open eyes, and the bolus was injected after 10 min, patients sat for an additional 10 minutes after
column321: For each procedure, an age- and weight-appropriate dose of 99mTc–hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime (HMPAO) SPECT was administered intravenously at rest and while performing a cognitive task
column799:
SPECT Functional Neuroimaging distinguishes adult ADHD patients without comorbidities from healthy controls with 100% sensitivity and specificity in post-hoc ROI analysis.
Visual reads of SPECT scans showed 100% sensitivity and >97% specificity in distinguishing adult ADHD from healthy controls.

column821: A high false-positive rate was observed in participants with Major Depressive Disorder, attributed to overlapping symptoms such as inattention and anxiety, which are common in both conditions. The high false-positive rate was attributed to symptom overlap, particularly with inattention and anxiety in depressive disorders.
column827: In patients with major depressive disorder (MDD), a negative ASRS-v1.1 screen strongly suggested the absence of ADHD, while a positive screen result required further evaluation to determine whether self-reported ADHD symptoms simply emerge from depression or co-morbid ADHD. column799:
QbTotal yielded the highest AUC value 0.87 (classified as ‘good’). ROCs indicate that at equivalent sensitivity of around 80%, QbTotal demonstrates superior specificity compared with CAARS-E in differentiating ADHD and autism spectrum disorder.

QbTest added to clinical ratings may improve the differentiation of ADHD and autism spectrum disorder in adults.

column708:
EEG (Electroencephalography) was recorded during transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) targeting the right prefrontal cortex and during the Stop Signal Task.
Stop Signal Task assesses the response inhibition and cognitive control by responding to visual cues and pressing corresponding buttons, the test serves as a paradigm to elicit neural activity for EEG recordings.
column711: Resting motor threshold (RMT) and coil positioning were first established. The coil was then moved 5 cm anterior to the motor spot and 2 cm to the right, handle of the coil pointed backward, perpendicularly to the presumed direction of the central sulcus, approximately 45◦ to the mid-sagittal line; stimulation intensity was set to 120%
column799: Significant reductions in transcranial magnetic stimulation-evoked potentials (TEPs) and event-related potentials (ERPs) in individuals with ADHD compared to healthy controls, as well as significant correlations between ADHD severity and TEP.

column799:
The overall discriminant validity of the CAARS was 69%, and it had an unacceptably high false positive and false negative rate. At lower prevalence rates, a high score on the CAARS has only a 22% chance of accurately identifying individuals with ADHD.
While the Exaggeration Index demonstrated high specificity (97%) in discriminating between those who are suspected or instructed to feign or exaggerate symptoms of ADHD and reduce false positives, its low sensitivity (24%) resulted in a significant number of false negatives, limiting its effectiveness in accurately identifying all true ADHD cases.{#347}

column624: Eye tracker, measuring modulation in the angle of eye vergence during an attention task using the BGaze eye-tracking system; participants were to maintain fixation on a central point while responding to visual stimuli, and the vergence angle (convergence or divergence of the eyes) was calculated using gaze vector data; a random forest classifier analyzed signals based on differential patterns in their eye vergence responses
column627: Participants sat in a dimly lit room of the hospital or clinic in front of the PC monitor (width = 503 mm and height = 375 mm) at a distance of 55 cm. During the totality of the task, a chin rest was used to prevent large head movements. The eye tracking equipment was calibrated (5 points, binocular) for each participant at the beginning of the experiment by BGaze eye tracking software. Before starting, the task was explained by the experimenter and all participants practiced with 20 trials to become familiar with the task. The entire procedure took approximately 15 min to complete.
column799: Eye Vergence Responses showed a diagnostic accuracy of 79%, with an AUC of 0.77, a false positive rate of 25%, and a false negative rate of 20.55%.

column799: While EEG connectivity could predict ADHD symptom severity, it did not reliably classify ADHD, 1st-degree relatives, and controls, with modest classification performance (AUC up to 0.669); EEG may serve as a neuromarker for ADHD symptoms, but its diagnostic utility remains limited due to variability in classification accuracy. Sensitivity (84%) and specificity (70%) of the self-report tool were calculated based on clinical diagnosis as the reference standard, indicating that self-reports were moderately effective at identifying individuals with ADHD but less accurate at ruling out false positives. Functional impairment (academic challenges) was also higher in the ADHD group, although similar complaints were noted among non-ADHD participants, indicating poor specificity for these academic concerns.

Individual neuropsychological tests showed high positive predictive power (83–100%), but negative predictive power was lower. When considering the entire test battery, classification accuracy improved significantly.

column408: Effort tests and symptoms validity tests are designed to assess the credibility of self-reported symptoms and detect intentional exaggeration or malingering. These tests include validity indices like the Negative Impression Management (NIM), Malingering Index (MAL), and Rogers Discriminant Function (RDF) in the Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI), which evaluate patterns of responses to identify response distortion. By analyzing these patterns, the tests differentiate genuine cases of ADHD from individuals feigning symptoms, providing insights into the reliability of the reported symptoms.
column799: The alternative cutoff scores of ≥77 on the Negative Impression Management (NIM) scale, ≥ three on the Malingering Index (MAL), and ≥ one on the Rogers Discriminant Function (RDF) yielded excellent specificity in all groups and sensitivities of 33, 30, and 20%, respectively.
column827: Misdiagnosis was more likely in individuals presenting with comorbid psychiatric conditions, such as anxiety or depression, as these conditions impacted validity index scores, potentially complicating differentiation between genuine and feigned symptoms.

column9: The study primarily evaluates the diagnostic accuracy of tools for diagnosing ADHD, focusing on the Integrated Visual and Auditory Continuous Performance Test (IVA CPT) and the ADHD Behavior Checklist. column408: Self-report (ADHD Behavior Checklist) and neuropsychological testing (IVA CPT) are both used to assess feigning ADHD. Malingerers successfully faked symptoms on self-reports but overcompensated on the IVA CPT. The IVA CPT served as a symptom validity test by detecting inconsistencies in response patterns and reaction times. Effort testing was implicit in the CPT, as malingerers exhibited unnatural response patterns.
column799: IVA CPT could not be faked on 81% of its scales. The CPT’s impairment index results revealed: sensitivity 94%, specificity 91%, PPP 88%, NPP 95%.

column408:
Conners Continuous Performance Test-3 (CPT-3) as an embedded validity indicator (EVI) to detect non-credible responders, which includes individuals feigning ADHD.
PVTs used as the reference standard, with non-credible responders classified based on failure of ≥2 PVTs. The CPT-3 indicators, including omissions, commissions, detectability, variability, and reaction time measures, are tested for their ability to distinguish between credible and feigned ADHD presentations.
CPT-3 indicators classification accuracy threshold (AUC ≥ 0.70)
column799: Receiver operating characteristic curves (ROC) revealed that 5/9 individual indicators and 2/4 composite indicators met a minimally acceptable classification accuracy of ≥ 0.70 (AUC = 0.43–0.78). Individual (0.16–0.45) and composite indicators (0.23–0.35) demonstrated low sensitivity when using cutoffs that maintained specificity ≥90%.

column827: The study noted a high prevalence of comorbid conditions, including depression (51%), anxiety disorders (28%), and personality disorders (23%), which could influence diagnostic accuracy and risk of misdiagnosis.
column830: The study recruited participants from a single psychiatric inpatient facility, and the sample was pre-selected to include individuals undergoing mental health assessment, which may not be representative of the broader ADHD population. This selection process could introduce bias, as patients with specific comorbidities or severe psychiatric conditions might be overrepresented.
column832: The same sample was used both to determine the cutoff for the IPDE-SQ 11-item subscale and to evaluate its diagnostic performance. This lack of a separate training and validation set could result in overfitting and an overestimation of diagnostic accuracy. Additionally, it is unclear whether the interpretation of the index test was blinded to the reference standard, which could further introduce bias.
column834: The reference standard used was a DSM-IV clinical interview conducted by a qualified mental health professional, which is considered a gold standard for diagnosing ADHD. The clinical interview comprehensively evaluated ADHD symptoms based on DSM-IV criteria, including persistence, severity, and impact across multiple domains of life, ensuring a reliable and valid classification of the condition. There is no indication that the reference standard was interpreted with knowledge of the index test results, further reducing the potential for bias.
column836: The study design was not randomized and did not ensure that all patients received the same reference standard and index test under comparable conditions. The retrospective nature of the data collection and the inclusion of patients from a single psychiatric facility introduces potential biases. Additionally, it is unclear whether the interval between the index test and the reference standard was consistent for all participants, which could impact diagnostic accuracy.
column850: Recruitment from a single psychiatric inpatient facility with a pre-selected population introduces bias, limiting generalizability. The same sample was used to determine the cutoff and evaluate performance, with no separate training and validation set, leading to overfitting concerns. The study lacked randomization, and inconsistencies in test timing and exclusions due to incomplete data contribute to potential bias.

column852: The study population consisted of patients from a psychiatric inpatient facility with high rates of comorbid conditions, such as depression, anxiety disorders, and personality disorders. column856: The study used the DSM-IV criteria for ADHD diagnosis, which may not align fully with the current DSM-5 standards. column799: The detectability index in Conners Continuous Performance Test-II had a sensitivity of 17% to detect ADHD and a specificity of 90% for feigning ADHD. Failing 1 or more, 2 or more, 3 or more, 4 or more cognitive feigning test indices lowered the sensitivity from 63 to 50, 47, and 35%, while the specificity increased from 82, to 93, 100%, and 100%. Indicates limited sensitivity in distinguishing ADHD from controls and susceptible to manipulation by feigning participants; results point to a need for a thorough evaluation of history, cognitive and emotional functioning, and the consideration of exaggerated symptomatology in the diagnosis of ADHD.

column799: Medical Symptom Validity Test showed the best performance (AUC 0.89, sensitivity 0.78, specificity 97).  Several processing speed and working memory scores from the WJ-IV effectively identified students feigning ADHD, detecting at least 50% of those students at score cutoffs that also maintained specificity of 90% or more, close to the efficiency of the standalone PVT. The study found that individuals simulating ADHD showed significantly lower scores on these measures compared to those with genuine ADHD, suggesting that working memory and processing speed deficits may help detect feigned ADHD.

column176: Clinical diagnoses of DSM-5 adult ADHD were made based on semistructured interviews using version 1.2 of the adult ADHD Clinical Diagnostic Scale.
column178: The ACDS was administered in the NCS-R by 4 experi- enced PhD-level clinical interviewers who received 40 hours of training from 2 board certified psychiatrists specializing in adult ADHD research (L.A.A. and T.J.S.). Each interviewer had to complete 5 practice interviews with symptom ratings match- ing those of the trainers before beginning the interviews. All production interviews were tape-recorded, reviewed by a clini- cal supervisor, and referred to the trainers (L.A.A. and T.J.S.) for final consensus diagnoses when supervisor-interviewer dis- crepancies occurred. The ACDS interviews in the managed care sample were administered by 6 PhD-level clinical psycholo- gists or MA-level social workers experienced in administer- ing the ACDS in clinical studies and trained by 1 of the inves- tigators (T.J.S.). The ACDS interviews in the NYU Langone sample were administered by 2 clinical psychology trainees (a PhD candidate with an MA, and an MA candidate with a BA), both trained by one of the investigators (L.A.A.). Ongoing group calibration meetings and reviews of a sample of tapes were used in all studies to ensure that symptom ratings on the ACDS con- formed to best practices. In the NCS-R, where the supervisor was not an expert in adult ADHD, we took the additional steps of having 1 such expert (L.A.A.) attend all group calibration meetings and of having the supervisor review 100% of the tapes and refer all discrepancies with interviewer ratings to the psy- chiatrists (L.A.A. and T.J.S.) for discussion and resolution.
column183: ASRS (Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale) screening scale developed to generate 1 fully structured question for each DSM-IV Criterion A1-A2 symptom of inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity plus 11 non–DSM-IV symptoms of deficits in higher-level executive function believed to be relevant to adult ADHD similar to the Utah Criteria for adult ADHD, each question asked how often the symptom occurred over the past 6 months with responses of never, rarely, sometimes, often, and very often
column185: The study explicitly developed and validated a short 6-question screening scale designed to detect DSM-5 ADHD in general population and clinical settings.

column799: The brief screening tool for ADHD demonstrated improved diagnostic accuracy among UK prison inmates, with a sensitivity of 0.82, specificity of 0.84, and overall accuracy of 0.84. column830: The study recruited a large, all-male sample of 392 inmates from HMP Inverness, with two exclusions due to missing data, resulting in 390 participants. All participants underwent the same diagnostic procedure, including both the BAARS-IV screening and the DIVA-2 diagnostic interview, regardless of their initial screening results.

column799:
Across self-report ADHD measures (ASRS-v1.1, Brown ADD Scale, WURS, CAARS-Self), the tests significantly differentiated adults diagnosed with ADHD from those without ADHD, with sensitivities ranging from 0.63–0.84 and specificities from 0.69–0.93, indicating generally good diagnostic utility.
Observer-rated ADHD symptoms (CAARS-Observer) distinguished adults with ADHD from those without ADHD with moderate sensitivity (0.76) and specificity (0.75) in a forensic outpatient population.
The computerized continuous performance test (IVA+Plus) showed low sensitivity (0.30–0.39) and modest specificity (0.69–0.74), indicating poor to moderate diagnostic accuracy for distinguishing adults with ADHD from non-ADHD participants.
The integrated variables of multiple self reports and an observer report demonstrated particularly good classification accuracy, with high sensitivity (91%) and good specificity (82%).

column863:
CAARS is a 66-item measure that contains 9 empirically-derived scales related to adult ADHD symptoms. The present analysis utilized the long form of the self-report and observer rated versions; the overall ADHD index was also used as the criterion for ADHD.
WURS is a 61-item self-report measure designed to assess a childhood history of ADHD in adults.
Brown ADD scale is a 40-item scale that measures symptoms associated with ADHD. The items are scored on a Likert-type scale and are grouped into five clus- ters: organizing and activating to work; sustaining attention and concentration; sustaining energy and effort; managing affective interference; and, utilizing working memory and accessing recall.

column799:
Parent ratings of childhood inattention had the highest predictive validity (AUC 0.79), outperforming self-report (AUC 0.56). 
Self-reports had high sensitivity (89%) but low specificity (30%), leading to a high false-positive rate.
The prediction model with both parent and student ratings of current symptoms and parent ratings of childhood symptoms accurately classified 88.9% of individuals who had a diagnosis of ADHD and 63.3% of individuals who did not have a diagnosis.

column273: Battery of neuropsychological tests, including AVLT (Auditory Verbal Learning Test) learning and recall scores, WAIS-III Processing Speed Index and Working Memory Index, TMT (Trail Making Test) Parts A and B, verbal fluency, and Stroop Color and Word Test (interference score)
column408: WMT (Word Memory Test) used as a symptom validity test to assess noncredible performance by measuring recognition memory under easy conditions with failure cutoffs at ≤82.5% for the first three subtests and ≤70% for the fourth subtest, conducted during neuropsychological evaluation at a university psychology clinic.
column799:
Self-report measures (WURS and CAARS) could not reliably distinguish ADHD from psychological controls, with substantial overlap in symptom endorsement between groups.
Neuropsychological tests did not reliably distinguish ADHD from psychological controls, except for the Stroop Interference score where ADHD participants performed worse.
Feigning ADHD was effectively identified by the Word Memory Test (WMT), with a 31% failure rate among referrals, and WMT failure associated with worse neuropsychological performance and higher symptom self-report across groups.
column803: WMT failure was associated with increased symptom reporting and worse neuropsychological performance, suggesting noncredible performance may distort both self-report and objective cognitive testing results.

column799:
SRSI distinguished participants faking ADHD from honest controls with a sensitivity of 82% and specificity of 90% at the screening cutoff of ≥7.
CAARS CII identified feigned ADHD with 65% sensitivity and 100% specificity using a cutoff of ≥21.
CAARS ACI had low sensitivity (24%) but perfect specificity (100%) for detecting simulated ADHD at a cutoff of ≥22.
RDS showed 67% sensitivity and 100% specificity for detecting noncredible performance using a cutoff of ≤6.
False positive rates for participants with an ADHD diagnosis ranged from 7.9% for the ACI to 48.7% for the SRSI (cut off 7).

column799:
CPT-3 (Conners Continuous Performance Test, Third Edition) distinguished adults with ADHD from healthy controls with 75.0% sensitivity, 79.3% specificity, and an AUC of 0.816.
fNIRS (functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy) during Verbal Fluency Task distinguished adults with ADHD from healthy controls with 77.5% sensitivity, 79.3% specificity, and an AUC of 0.841.
Oculomotricity measures from prosaccade, antisaccade, and memory-guided saccade tasks distinguished adults with ADHD from healthy controls with 71.3% sensitivity, 77.2% specificity, and an AUC of 0.795.
A combined model using fNIRS, oculomotricity, and CPT-3 achieved 80.3% sensitivity, 84.5% specificity, and an AUC of 0.892 in distinguishing adults with ADHD from healthy controls.

column799:
CAARS-HI ≥ 80 distinguished simulators from ADHD and control participants with 35.6% sensitivity, 100% specificity to controls, and 1.3% false positives in ADHD participants.
CII ≥ 21 distinguished simulators from ADHD and control participants with 39.7% sensitivity, 99.6% specificity to controls, and 7% false positives in ADHD participants.
EI ≥ 4 distinguished simulators from ADHD and control participants with 42.7% sensitivity, 98.5% specificity to controls, and 12.2% false positives in ADHD participants.
DES SVT ≥ 24 had 45.2% sensitivity, 94.2% specificity to controls, and 27.5% false positives in ADHD participants.
SAMS ≥ 28 had over 90% sensitivity but poor specificity, classifying most ADHD participants as noncredible (>60% false positives).
